Hopkins has the oil!!
What's turning out to be the coldest winter of the
century has yet to pose serious problems for the
Homewood campus. In the midst of record lows and a
state of emergency through much of the Northeast and
Mid-Atlantic, Hopkins has managed to operate smoothly
with a steady fuel supply.
The University has escaped the natural gas crisis because
it is an interruptible customer, and Baltimore Gas and
Electric had discontinued service on November 1. As one
of the lowest priority customers, Hopkins had been told of
the November cut-off date well in advance (and also much
before any indication of the present cold spell). Last year,
the University had gone only the month of November
without regular service; this time, Director of Plant
Planning and Operations Bill Campbell expects the cut-off
to stretch to 150 days.
In the meantime, Hopkins will rely almost exclusively
on oil. The supplier, Shipley-Humble of York, Pa., expects
"no immediate problem" with the fuel supply, although
tanker shipment has obviously been halted by a frozen
Chesapeake Bay. While Number 2 oil customers (including
homes and Goucher College, among others) have been
hampered by the severe winter, the University, using
heavier, cruder Number 6 grade oil, has had little difficulty
with supply.
The places on campus which do require gas—the dorm
and Levering cafeterias—will not be affected by Governor
Mandel's request for restaurants to close periodically. In
the Bradford apartments, the only other University-owned
building using natural gas, temperatures will be lowered to
the 60-65 degree range.
Campbell said that thermostats will be reset throughout
the campus to comply with the BG&E and Mandel
recommendations. "It isn't that we haven't been involved
in energy conservation since the oil embargo in 1973," he
noted. "It's just that after all the publicity, individuals
tend to forget how institutions are operating.
As an interruptible gas customer, Hopkins has kept a
secure secondary fuel supply—oil—to avoid the closings
that area restaurants, stores and public schools face. With
the extreme cold expected to last through February,
Cambell doesn't anticipate any sudden unavailability of
oil. "We'll know very much in advance if something drastic
is going to happen," he commented. "But continued hard
weather could have nothing but a bad effect."

Report is released
Follett's must go!
By G.B. ZELINSKY
The Student Council's
Bookstore Taskforce culminated
its three-month study of
Bookcenter problems with the
release of a report that presented
the committee's findings and
outlined alternative proposals.
In the sixteen-page report
released last Friday, the taskforce
reviewed a number of recurring
complaints against Follett's JHU
Bookcenter. The problems
included shortages of required
readings, late-arriving orders,
Poor faculty/management
communication, as well as
inaccurate and conflicting prices.
Taskforce chairman Sheldon
Himelfarb stressed that the
objective of the inquiry was not
to compare Follett's prices to
those of other profit-oriented
college bookstores. Instead, it
was meant to point out the
inconsistencies inherent in
allowing any profit-motivated
firm to run Hopkins' bookstore,
at a time when the Muller
Administration is stressing "the
importance of financial
responsibility for all areas of the
Johns Hopkins University."
Himelfarb went on to say that
the report was intended to spur
the Administration towards some
sort of decision in the matter.
The report also examined five

alternatives to a
privately-managed bookstore.
The first proposal would retain
the current structure of the store,
but bring it under university
ownership and management.
Himelfarb admitted that because
of the disastrous failure of the
previous attempt at
University -ownership,
administration officials have been
less than enthusiastic about the
prospect of the bookstore
reverting to school control.
Another plan would combine the
management of the Homewood
store with the Med School
bookstore (already operated by
the University), in order to
maximize buying power on
supplies and luxury items, as well
as add the "expertise of an
already established operation." A
third proposal (endorsed by the
Student Council) would establish
a co-op, with a possible
membership fee for participants.
In order for the co-op to operate
successfully, Himelfarb
explained, it would have to be
"in the hands of top-level
experienced management,
possibly hired from outside the
school" Other alternatives
included a book exchange
(dealing
strictly in texts)
and a combination book co-op
and university store.

President Muller puts foot down on calendar changes

By MICITEL STEVEN KRUG
HomeWood students will not
be obliged to take final
examinations after Christmas or
classes on Saturdays during the
1978-79 academic year informed
sources reported yesterday.
A confidential source said
Presiden, Steven Muller will be
advised to continue the present
setup for finals, although the
preliminary reading and study
period are still in question. Also,
the status of Intersession
continues to be uncertain.
Muller's calendar proposal,
designed I to coordinate academic
resources and schedules between
the Homewood and East
Baltimore campuses, would
lengthen the first semester by
one week. Finals for Homewood
students would be administered
the week before Christmas break,
using the extra week.
Undergraduates enrolled in East
Baltimore classes, however,
would still take finals in January
in accordance with the schedule
of that campus.
Muller would not confirm the
change from his previous position
"at this time." It might be a
likely outcome, but I can't say
it's a decision yet," he said.
Both Muller and George Owen,
Dean of Arts and Sciences said
Homewood students will not
have Saturday classes, unless
organic chemistry laboratories
are overcrowded, or a student
takes a course at East Baltimore.
In tandem with the Muller
proposal, a task force of Medical

and science professors from East
Baltimore have constructed the
so-called Lehninger proposal
(after
Albert Lehninger, a
leading member of the task force
committee). Under the proposal,
the structure of the first two
years of Medical school or
scientific programs would be
altered to allow students to make
greater use of Arts and Science
classes offered at Homewood,
and additional faculty will be
added to the Medical School. In
addition, Saturday classes will be
reinstituted at East Baltimore.
Other than lab classes, East
Baltimore has not had Saturday
classes for ten years.
Professors contacted generally
supported the Lehninger
proposal. "Over the years the
increased opportunity to take
classes at more than one campus
will be good," said Dr. Vernon
Mountcastle, Professor and
Director of the Physiology
Department. He said he will not
mind teaching Saturday classes
again, because "in the Medical
school it's been a long
tradition. '
Dr. Richard J. Johns, Professor
and Director of Biomedical
Engineering also supported the
Muller and Lehninger proposals.
"Our Bio-Medical Ph.D. program
involved both course work in arts
and sciences during Med-school.
We have a real compatibility
problem with the present
calendar," he said.
Both professors, however, said
transportation between campuses

could be a problem for students
and faculty. The Muller proposal
allows for transportation time by
scheduling Homewood classes to
begin on the half hour while East
Baltimore classes begin on the
;hour.

To the editor:
I was indeed offended by the
News-Letter's article on the
Carter inauguration, not that I
worship the president or the
presidency, but that the article
was symptomatic of the pointless
pokes at what promises to be an
administration of considerable
progress. The concentration of
News-Letter criticism on the
inaugural and the pardoninw
shows a misdirection common in
many criticisms of Carter:
attacks on largely symbolic
elements of an administration
showing much more than
symbolic change. To have given
columns of print to the
inauguration a subject that will
be forgotten tomorrow, and to
give none to the economic
stimulus'. program is simply
terrible reporting.
But even worse is the idiot
harping on the problems of the
inauguration: there has been no
event of such size in this country
with, as reported. as few as seven
minor injuries. Even beyond
confusion, the criticism makes an
odd sort of inside sarcasm about
.what is called the people's
inaugural. Sure tickets wen-

twenty five dollars: and what are
we to compare this with: the '72
inaugural, which required tickets
well into the thousands? Sure,
the mass invitations were largely
symbolic, but isn't it nice to have
a president who is willing to
make a gesture to the common
man, not fearing him, as we have
so sharply seen in the past? The
ideal was to have a free inaugural
with all the US, including
Bankers, including sharecroppers,
attending, but is that possible?
To use an ideal to criticise a real
change is merely self-destructive;
the same impulse almost gave
McCarthy enough votes to elect a
man who by no view was the
people's president: Ford. And
such useless idealism is
threataning [sic] to hamstring
any positive action on the part of
any President; the unachievable
perfectionist idealogies of the far
left, and the far right, are merely
being used to leave America in a
directionless abyss. The
News-Letter should be glad to
have a man who isn't more
concerned with the pensions of
the rich than the starvation of
the poor. Any further, no matter
how glittering prospects such
ideals may be, is either
impossible or implausible in
America. And remember; it was
the reform of FDR which made
possible America's rejection of
outmoded big business Smithian
economics: not the unsuccessful
pies in the skys of Norman
Thomas; it was the domestic
reform of LBJ which makes
possible a true welfare state in
this country, not the airy
generalizations of the McCarthy
New Left. So Carter is working in
a tradition of actual success, not
merely slogans.
Josiah Heyman

By STEVE SCHULTZ
The controversy surrounding
"affirmative action" in education
has been re-ignited by a recent
decision by the Supreme Court
of California that a special
admissions program violated the
equal protection clause of the
14th Amendment.
In 1974, Allan Bakke, a
36-year-old engineer, charged in a
lawsuit against the University of
California Medical School at
Davis that he was a victim of
"invidious discrimination"
because of the color of his
skin---white. He had applied for
admission in 1973 and 1974 and
had been rejected both times. Mr.
Bakke had a 3.51 grade point
average.
The Medical School had
admitted 100 students in its first
year class. Sixteen places were
reserved for "educationally or
economically disadvantaged
students." These places were
filled by minority students, some
of whose grade point averages fell
below 2.5. In the regular
admissions program, applicants
whose GPA fell below 2.5 were
summarily denied admission.
The court held that "the
program, as administered by the
university, violated the rights
guaranteed to nonminority
applicants by the equal
protection clause of the U.S.
Constitution because it afforded
preference on the basis of race to
persons who, by the university's
own standards, were not as
qualified for the study of
medicine as nonminority
applicants denied admission." A similar case arose in 1974
regarding admission to law
school. In Marco Defunis v. the
University of Washington Law
School, the U.S. Supreme Court
sidestepped the crucial issue,
declaring the case moot since
Defunis had been finally
admitted and was about to
graduate. In a dissent, former
Supreme Court Justice Douglas
stated: "There is no
constitutional right for any race
to be preferred....There is no
superior person by constitutional
standards. A Defunis who is
white is entitled to no advantage
by reason of th at fact; nor is he
subject to any disability no
matter what his race or color.
Whatever his race, he had a
constitutional right to have his
application considered on its
individual merits in a racially
neutral manner." (emphasis
mine)
In addition, Justice Douglas
declared that the equal
protection clause "commands the
elimination of racial barriers, not
their creation in order to satisfy
our theory as to how society
ought to be organized."
Minority admissions program were an outgrowth of the sixties
civil rights movement which
sought full integration of
minorities into the business and
academic communities.
Institutions of higher learning
undertook a vigorous recruitment
of minority students, increased
financial assistance, and
established remedial programs for
those of poor educational
background. The rationale that
underlay such efforts was- that

applicants from groups
historically discriminated against
would not be excluded due to
low grades or poor scores on
standardized admission tests. A
truly diverse student body ww.
seen as a benefit to the large'
society, for education has always
been perceived by reformers as a
"foot in the door" to those
previously excluded from the
academic system.
Proponents of "affirmative
action" today use many of these
same arguments-- special
admissions will encourage
responsible leadership among
minority groups, provide
guidance and inspiration to
minority youth, and build
confidence in a legal system that
has previously been indifferent, if
not blatantly opposed, to their
interests and needs.

Those in favor of such
programs point out that race is
not only relevant but a major
factor in the admissions process.
They argue that we should not
deceive ourselves into believing
the myth of society according to
meritocracy.
One commentator has stated:
"Efforts to equalized access to
higher learning for minority
students exemplify the paradox
of institutional racism -- that

Hopkins has the oil!!
What's turning out to be the coldest winter of the
century has yet to pose serious problems for the
Homewood campus. In the midst of record lows and a
state of emergency through much of the Northeast and
Mid-Atlantic, Hopkins has managed to operate smoothly
with a steady fuel supply.
The University has escaped the natural gas crisis because
it is an interruptible customer, and Baltimore Gas and
Electric had discontinued service on November 1. As one
of the lowest priority customers, Hopkins had been told of
the November cut-off date well in advance (and also much
before any indication of the present cold spell). Last year,
the University had gone only the month of November
without regular service; this time, Director of Plant
Planning and Operations Bill Campbell expects the cut-off
to stretch to 150 days.
In the meantime, Hopkins will rely almost exclusively
on oil. The supplier, Shipley-Humble of York, Pa., expects
"no immediate problem" with the fuel supply, although
tanker shipment has obviously been halted by a frozen
Chesapeake Bay. While Number 2 oil customers (including
homes and Goucher College, among others) have been
hampered by the severe winter, the University, using
heavier, cruder Number 6 grade oil, has had little difficulty
with supply.
The places on campus which do require gas—the dorm
and Levering cafeterias—will not be affected by Governor
Mandel's request for restaurants to close periodically. In
the Bradford apartments, the only other University-owned
building using natural gas, temperatures will be lowered to
the 60-65 degree range.
Campbell said that thermostats will be reset throughout
the campus to comply with the BG&E and Mandel
recommendations. "It isn't that we haven't been involved
in energy conservation since the oil embargo in 1973," he
noted. "It's just that after all the publicity, individuals
tend to forget how institutions are operating.
As an interruptible gas customer, Hopkins has kept a
secure secondary fuel supply—oil—to avoid the closings
that area restaurants, stores and public schools face. With
the extreme cold expected to last through February,
Cambell doesn't anticipate any sudden unavailability of
oil. "We'll know very much in advance if something drastic
is going to happen," he commented. "But continued hard
weather could have nothing but a bad effect."

By STEVE SCHULTZ
The controversy surrounding
"affirmative action" in education
has been re-ignited by a recent
decision by the Supreme Court
of California that a special
admissions program violated the
equal protection clause of the
14th Amendment.
In 1974, Allan Bakke, a
36-year-old engineer, charged in a
lawsuit against the University of
California Medical School at
Davis that he was a victim of
"invidious discrimination"
because of the color of his
skin---white. He had applied for
admission in 1973 and 1974 and
had been rejected both times. Mr.
Bakke had a 3.51 grade point
average.
The Medical School had
admitted 100 students in its first
year class. Sixteen places were
reserved for "educationally or
economically disadvantaged
students." These places were
filled by minority students, some
of whose grade point averages fell
below 2.5. In the regular
admissions program, applicants
whose GPA fell below 2.5 were
summarily denied admission.
The court held that "the
program, as administered by the
university, violated the rights
guaranteed to nonminority
applicants by the equal
protection clause of the U.S.
Constitution because it afforded
preference on the basis of race to
persons who, by the university's
own standards, were not as
qualified for the study of
medicine as nonminority
applicants denied admission." A similar case arose in 1974
regarding admission to law
school. In Marco Defunis v. the
University of Washington Law
School, the U.S. Supreme Court
sidestepped the crucial issue,
declaring the case moot since
Defunis had been finally
admitted and was about to
graduate. In a dissent, former
Supreme Court Justice Douglas
stated: "There is no
constitutional right for any race
to be preferred....There is no
superior person by constitutional
standards. A Defunis who is
white is entitled to no advantage
by reason of th at fact; nor is he
subject to any disability no
matter what his race or color.
Whatever his race, he had a
constitutional right to have his
application considered on its
individual merits in a racially
neutral manner." (emphasis
mine)
In addition, Justice Douglas
declared that the equal
protection clause "commands the
elimination of racial barriers, not
their creation in order to satisfy
our theory as to how society
ought to be organized."
Minority admissions program were an outgrowth of the sixties
civil rights movement which
sought full integration of
minorities into the business and
academic communities.
Institutions of higher learning
undertook a vigorous recruitment
of minority students, increased
financial assistance, and
established remedial programs for
those of poor educational
background. The rationale that
underlay such efforts was- that

applicants from groups
historically discriminated against
would not be excluded due to
low grades or poor scores on
standardized admission tests. A
truly diverse student body ww.
seen as a benefit to the large'
society, for education has always
been perceived by reformers as a
"foot in the door" to those
previously excluded from the
academic system.
Proponents of "affirmative
action" today use many of these
same arguments-- special
admissions will encourage
responsible leadership among
minority groups, provide
guidance and inspiration to
minority youth, and build
confidence in a legal system that
has previously been indifferent, if
not blatantly opposed, to their
interests and needs.

Those in favor of such
programs point out that race is
not only relevant but a major
factor in the admissions process.
They argue that we should not
deceive ourselves into believing
the myth of society according to
meritocracy.
One commentator has stated:
"Efforts to equalized access to
higher learning for minority
students exemplify the paradox
of institutional racism -- that
neutral institutional responses to
situations in which prior
discrimination have produced
minority inequality do not
produce equality of result, but
crystallize the effects of past
inequities." According to this
view, racial classification as a
practical matter must be
employed to counteract historic
racism. It is argued that there
exists a distinction between
"invidious" and remedial or
"benign 'discrimination.
The latter argument, grounded
on semantics, is effectively
meaningless. Larry Lavinsky, a
New York lawyer who is national
chairman of the civil rights
division of the Anti- Defamation
League, comments: "The
argument that a racial
classification which discriminates
against white people is not
inherently suspect, implies that
the white majority is monolithic
and so politcally powerful as not
to require the constitutional
safeguards afforded minority
racial groups. But the white
majority is pluralistic, containin
within itself a multitude of
religious and other ethnic
minorities -- Catholics, Jews.
Italians, Irish, Poles -- and many
others who are vulnerable to
prejudice and who to this day
suffer the effects of past
discrimination.

Such groups have only
recently. begun to enjoy the
benefits of a free society and
should mot be exposed to new
discriminatory bars, even if th ey
are raised in the cause of
compensation to certain racial
minorities for past inequities."
Progressive legal organizations
such as the American Civil
Liberties Union and the National
Lawyers Guild have begun to
speak out against what they
consider "backsliding" on the
part of the medical and legal
establishments in their promises
to "open up." Their argument
has a seeming illogic to it—that
equality, in this case, justifies, if
not requires, discrimination. The
Bay Area Third World Students
Alliance has stated: "the recent
California Supreme Court
decision is another blow struck at
the few hard-won gains in rights
of minority peoples."
Opponents of reverse
discrimination constitute a varied
group, many of whom were the
most enthusiastic supporters of
civil rights struggles of the last
decade. They contend that while
an integrated education is an
appropriate social goak, the
manner in which this is being
achieved is racist in the true sense
of the word. The Washington
State Supreme Court ruling in
favor of Defunis is generally
supportive of this belief—"the
minority admissions policy is
certainly not benign with respect
to nonminority students who are•
displaced by it."

Criterion
Critics feel that the criterion
for special admissions programs
should not be solely skin color
but economic disadvantagement,
so that whites as well as blacks
may qualify. Many believe that
the admission of unqualified
students by professional schools
results in a lowering of standards.
Others have pointed out that
admission under these
circumstances actually
constitutes as "handicap"for the
applicants themselves Self-confidence of minority
students is undermined when
they feel that their place in class
is a function of race, and not
demonstrated ability and
academic promise.
Admission policies in graduate
education programs should not
be ridden by racial quotas
rather, they should be flexible
enough to encompass a number
of factors in addition to grades
and test scores: personal
interviews, recommendations,
character, and cultural
background. If two students of
equal academic ability are
seeking admission, the minority
student should be given
preference. However, to choose
one applicant over another solely
because the former is black,
chicano, or Puerto Rican is
clearly an affront to the applicant
as well as society at large.
In the last analysis, such
discriminatory behavior is not
corrective but generates further
racism and resistance to
integration. The case for
"affirmative action," then, is an
argument for deprivation. The
search for social justice is
ill-served by its application.
